item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Libya’s Unexpected Strength
item.description: Although the country faces debilitating weaknesses, a popular consensus on major issues transcends cleavages over smaller ones.
item.dc:creator: By DIRK VANDEWALLE and NICHOLAS JAHR

item.title: Explosion Levels Hotel Housing Government Troops in Syria
item.description: Activist groups and state television said rebels tunneled underneath a hotel in Aleppo to plant remotely detonated explosives.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Blast Hits Pakistani Army Convoy, Killing 9 Soldiers
item.description: The attack in the tribal areas came as peace talks between the Pakistani government and the Taliban have been faltering.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Hesitates to Label Guangzhou Attack Terrorism
item.description: Instead, they have described the incident as a “knife attack,” suggesting the possibility that it was the work of a lone assailant with no connection to militants from the northwestern region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: China’s Exports and Imports Return to Slight Growth
item.description: The April figures beat market forecasts and offered some positive signals for the world’s second-largest economy after a weak start to 2014.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: At Election Season’s End, Sri Lankan Tamil Refugees Forgotten Again
item.description: Political leaders in Tamil Nadu usually pay little attention to the refugees’ dire living conditions, but in every election season, parties compete to portray themselves as champions of the Sri Lankan Tamils.
item.dc:creator: By VIABHAV VATS

item.title: Preliminary Results Show A.N.C. Leading in South African Vote
item.description: With half of the votes counted, interim figures showed the party was in danger of winning a smaller share of the vote than it did in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Ukrainians Favor Unity, Not Russia, Polls Find
item.description: Two polls conducted by the Pew Research Center last month, after the annexation of Crimea, found two-thirds of Ukrainians believe that Russia is a bad influence.
item.dc:creator: By MARJORIE CONNELLY

item.title: Hired by Clermont Foot, Helena Costa Sets Major Soccer Milestone
item.description: Helena Costa, the former coach of the Qatar and Iran women’s national teams, will become the first woman to coach a men’s professional team in France.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: Helena Costa, 36, worked recently as manager of the women’s national teams of Qatar and Iran.

item.title: Dissident Journalist Held Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: Chinese authorities, who are wary of dissent as the occasion approaches, arrested the outspoken Gao Yu under a state secrets law that critics call vague and overly broad.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 8
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: More Hugs Please, We’re Chinese
item.description: The act of hugging, once a rarity in China, is becoming more commonplace as increasing exposure to less physically reserved cultures lowers resistance to warm embraces.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman and child hugged each other near a portrait of Sun Yat-sen, first president of the Republic of China, in Tiananmen Square ahead of May Day.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Civil Society Activists Detained as Anniversary Looms
item.description: The Beijing police detained as many as nine activists planning a seminar on obstacles facing gay groups, one of the organizers said, a sign of the authorities’ anxiety as the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown approaches.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Yu Fangqiang, from his Sina Weibo homepage.

item.title: Real Threat in a Known Market for Children
item.description: The threat by the leader of the Boko Haram to sell the missing Nigerian girls has brought a focus on the ease of child trafficking in the developing world, human rights investigators said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A video screengrab shows a man claiming to be the leader of Boko Haram last year.

item.title: Abduction of Girls an Act Not Even Al Qaeda Can Condone
item.description: Boko Haram, the Nigerian group that has carried out mass kidnappings, was rejected long ago by mainstream Muslims, but its recent abductions appeared too much even for fellow militants to condone.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Four abducted students were reunited with their families in Chibok, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Putin Announces Pullback From Ukraine Border
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pressed pause on Wednesday in what had begun to look like an inevitable march toward war in Ukraine, but world leaders questioned whether it was a feint.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a meeting with Didier Burkhalter, the president of Switzerland, on Wednesday in Moscow.

item.title: U.N. Agency to Consider Ways to Track Planes Over Oceans
item.description: The United Nations’ civil aviation arm, weighing action after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, has dozens of competing proposals to sort through.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Populist Party Gaining Muscle to Push Britain to the Right
item.description: The UK Independence Party is expected to make a strong showing in the European Parliament elections starting May 22.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nigel Farage leads the UK Independence Party, which has emerged from the fringes in Britain.

item.title: Tehran Journal: When Freedom Is the Right to Stay Under Wraps
item.description: Iranian men and women in black chadors made their way through Tehran’s afternoon rush on Wednesday, shouting for the government to arrest all women who are improperly veiled.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A rally Wednesday in Tehran to try to compel the government to arrest improperly veiled women. As summer approaches, more women are flouting Iran’s obligatory Islamic dress code.

item.title: U.N. May Refer Syria Conflict to War Crimes Court
item.description: A carefully worded draft Security Council resolution aims to send Syria to the International Criminal Court while protecting American sensitivities.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Syrian Rebels Depart Homs District Under Deal
item.description: The pullout, under the terms of a deal that gives the district to government forces, is a bitter defeat for the insurgents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian government soldiers patrolled a devastated street in Homs last year.

item.title: Young Ukrainians Brush Aside the Crisis and Voice Optimism About the Future
item.description: In spite of the daily chaos, conflict and crisis, 20- and 30-somethings insist that Ukraine has a brighter future in store, and they say they can build it.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nataliya Gumenyuk, 30, in Kiev in February. “My state perhaps cannot defend me, but it’s not acting against me,” she said.

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Exiles Arrested on Terror Charges
item.description: Four Cuban exiles from Miami are being held for planning “terrorist actions” against military targets on the island, authorities said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : Indonesia: Shariah Official Urges That Gang-Rape Victim Be Caned
item.description: An Indonesian woman who was gang-raped by men who accused her of having extramarital sex may be caned publicly for violating Islamic law, an official said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Arrests in Shooting of Antigovernment Protester
item.description: The authorities on Wednesday said they had charged two sergeants in the country’s National Guard in the death of a 23-year-old woman who was shot during antigovernment protests.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
